hints_html: If\(A=C^{-1}BC\), then \(A\), \(B\) are similar matrices.
question: 6 (b)
sols_html:
By the equation \(A = C^{-1}BC\), we can see that \(A,B\) are similar matrices.

One of the properties of similar matrices is that their determinants are equal. Hence,

\[\begin{aligned} {\color{blue}\operatorname{Det}(A) = \operatorname{Det}(B) =12}\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
By the equation <math>A = C^{-1}BC</math>, we can see that <math>A,B</math> are <b>similar</b> matrices.

One of the properties of similar matrices is that their determinants are equal. <font style="color:blue;">Hence,
:<math>
{\color{blue}\operatorname{Det}(A) = \operatorname{Det}(B) = 12}
</math></font>
statement_html:
This question requires little or no calculations.

If \(A=C^{-1}BC\), where C is an invertible matrix, and det B=12, det C=-3. Calculate det A.
statement_latex:
This question requires little or no calculations.

If $A=C^{-1}BC$, where \emph{C} is an invertible matrix, and det
\emph{B}=12, det \emph{C}=-3. Calculate det \emph{A}.
statement_raw:
This question requires little or no calculations.

If <math>A=C^{-1}BC</math>, where ''C'' is an invertible matrix, and det ''B''=12, det ''C''=-3.  Calculate det ''A''.
